organization.fullName: University of St. Augustine for Health Sciences

identificationModule.briefTitle: Rock Steady Boxing: A Community Based In Person Class
identificationModule.officialTitle: Rock Steady Boxing: A Community Based In Person Class for Patients With Parkinson Disease

leadSponsor.name: University of St. Augustine for Health Sciences

descriptionModule.briefSummary:
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the feasibility and effectiveness of a non-contact Rock Steady Boxing class delivered to participants with Parkinson's Disease via an in-person community-based program. The study will also assess the overall feasibility of integrating an in-person community program within a neuromuscular course in a Doctor of Physical Therapy program.

Specific Aim: To examine the effects of an in-person community-based Rock Steady Boxing class on the functional mobility, functional endurance, cardiovascular capacity, visual-motor reaction times, quality of life, mood/affect and overall physical activity completion and fear of falling on individuals with Parkinson's Disease.
descriptionModule.detailedDescription: Participants will be recruited directly from the the Brain Center (non-for-profit neurology clinic). Participants will be educated on the study but advised that their participation is voluntary and researchers will not coerce boxers to participate in the study. Once a participant agrees to participate, the Informed consent will be completed. During this time, participants will be told their participation is voluntary and they can quit at any time. he primary interventions being assessed in this study include the in-person Rock Steady Boxing Class offered at USAHS once per week. Prior to attending the Rock Steady Boxing classes, all participants must be provided with medical clearance from a referring medical doctor. The Rock Steady Boxing classes are 60-90 minutes in duration and include the following 4 components: (1) active warm up (2) functional mobility exercises (3) whole body strengthening exercises and (4) non-contact boxing exercises. During the classes, boxers' vitals are assessed using health rate monitors.

armGroups.label: Rock Steady Boxing classes
armGroups.description: The Rock Steady Boxing classes are 60-90 minutes in duration twice a week and include the following 4 components: (1) active warm up (2) functional mobility exercises (3) whole body strengthening exercises and (4) non-contact boxing exercises.

interventions.name: Rock Steady Boxing Class
interventions.description: Rock Steady Boxing is a non-contact fitness program designed specifically for people with Parkinson's Disease.

primaryOutcomes.measure: Changes over time in Activities-Specific Balance Confidence Scale (ABC) from baseline to one year
primaryOutcomes.description: The ABC is a self-report measure of balance confidence in performing various activities without losing balance or experiencing a sense of unsteadiness.

primaryOutcomes.measure: Changes in Falls Efficacy Scale - International from baseline to 1-year post
primaryOutcomes.description: A self-administered questionnaire designed to assess fear of falling in mainly community-dwelling older population

primaryOutcomes.measure: Changes in Parkinson's Disease Fatigue Scale from baseline to 1-year post
primaryOutcomes.description: A patient-rated scale that measures fatigue

primaryOutcomes.measure: Changes in Parkinson's Disease Questionnaire -39 from baseline to 1-year post
primaryOutcomes.description: A 39-item self-report questionnaire, which assesses Parkinson's disease-specific health related quality over the last month.

primaryOutcomes.measure: Changes in Physical Activity Scale for the Elderly (PASE) from baseline to 1-year post
primaryOutcomes.description: The PASE measures the level of self-reported physical activity in individuals aged 65 years old or older and is comprised of items regarding occupational, household, and leisure activity during the previous 7-day period.

primaryOutcomes.measure: Changes in Berg Balance Test from baseline to 1-year post
primaryOutcomes.description: The Berg Balance Scale (BBS) is used to objectively determine a patient's ability (or inability) to safely balance during a series of predetermined tasks.

primaryOutcomes.measure: Changes in 10-Meter Walk Test from baseline to 1-year post
primaryOutcomes.description: The 10 Meter Walk Test is a performance measure used to assess walking speed in meters per second over a short distance.

primaryOutcomes.measure: Changes in 6-Minute Walk Test from baseline to 1-year post
primaryOutcomes.description: The 6 Minute Walk Test is a sub-maximal exercise test used to assess aerobic capacity and endurance.

primaryOutcomes.measure: Changes in Time Up and Go (TUG) from baseline to 1-year post
primaryOutcomes.description: Measure of function with correlates to balance and fall risk

primaryOutcomes.measure: Changes in Self-Efficacy for Exercise from baseline to 1-year post
primaryOutcomes.description: Self report measure of exercise self-efficacy

primaryOutcomes.measure: Changes in Anticipatory & Compensatory Postural Assessment form baseline to 1-year post
primaryOutcomes.description: Electromyography measure of postural stability in standing

primaryOutcomes.measure: Changes in Rock Steady Boxing Questionnaire from 3-month post to 1-year post intervention
primaryOutcomes.description: Self assessment of mobility and quality of life

primaryOutcomes.measure: Changes Physical Activity Intensity Monitoring from baseline to 1-year post intervention

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

1. Male or Female
2. Age Range: 18 years or older
3. History of Parkinson's Disease between Hoehn and Yarh stages I and IV
4. Medical clearance from a referring medical doctor
5. Able to complete all assessments
6. Willing to complete a weekly exercise log

Exclusion Criteria:

1. Unable to complete the assessments.
2. Pregnant or is expected to become pregnant during study
3. Other reasons that may limit participation in exercises. -

overallOfficials.name: Miguel Garcia, EdD
overallOfficials.affiliation: University of St Augustine for Health Science

locations.facility: University of St Augustine for Health Science

ipdSharingStatementModule.description: Data obtained through this study may be provided to qualified researchers with academic interest in rehabilitation for individuals with Parkinson's Disease. Data or samples shared will be coded, with no Private Health Information included. Approval of the request and execution of all applicable agreements are prerequisites to the sharing of data with the requesting party.
ipdSharingStatementModule.timeFrame: Data requests can be submitted starting 9 months after article publication and the data will be made accessible for up to 24 months. Extensions will be considered on a case-by-case basis.
ipdSharingStatementModule.accessCriteria: Access to trial Individual Patient Data can be requested by qualified researchers engaging in independent scientific research, and will be provided following review and approval of a research proposal and Statistical Analysis Plan and execution of a Data Sharing Agreement.
